questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is terrified of going to the doctor's office for his vaccinations. His mother notices that he becomes anxious and cries every time he sees a white lab coat, even when they are not at the doctor's office. This phenomenon is best explained by which of the following psychological principles?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Classical conditioning

 

Option A:

 

Classical conditioning is a learning process in which a neutral stimulus (conditioned stimulus) becomes associated with a meaningful stimulus (unconditioned stimulus), leading to a similar response. In this case, the white lab coat (neutral stimulus) has become associated with the painful experience of vaccinations (meaningful stimulus), causing the child to become anxious and cry when seeing a white lab coat.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Operant conditioning involves learning through the consequences of behavior, such as rewards or punishments. This process is not applicable to the situation described, as the child's response to the lab coat is not based on the consequences of his behavior.

 

Option C. Observational learning involves learning through watching others and imitating their behaviors. The child's fear of the white lab coat is not based on observing others' behavior, so this option is not applicable.

 

Option D. Habituation is a decrease in response to a stimulus over time due to repeated exposure. In this case, the child's response to the white lab coat has not decreased, so habituation does not explain the phenomenon.

 

Educational objective:

 

Classical conditioning is a learning process where an association is formed between a neutral stimulus and a naturally occurring stimulus that elicits a response. In this case, the child has been classically conditioned to associate the sight of a white lab coat with the fear and anxiety of getting vaccinations, causing him to react with anxiety and crying even when seeing a white lab coat outside of the doctor's office.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 1015.

choices.text: Alcohol withdrawal with perceptual disturbances.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male with a history of daily alcohol consumption presents to the emergency department approximately 10 hours after his last drink. He complains of anxiety, palpitations, and shakiness in his hands. On examination, you observe coarse, rhythmic tremors of his outstretched hands. Which of the following best describes this clinical manifestation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Alcohol withdrawal tremors.

 

Option C:

 

The patient's presentation is consistent with alcohol withdrawal syndrome, and the tremors described are characteristic of alcohol withdrawal tremors. Alcohol withdrawal tremors, especially of the outstretched hands, are one of the earliest signs of alcohol withdrawal and can start as early as 6-8 hours after the last drink. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alcohol withdrawal with perceptual disturbances. This is characterized primarily by auditory hallucinations and can occur 12-24 hours after the last drink. Though the patient may have tremors, hallucinosis would have auditory (and sometimes visual) hallucinations as its primary feature.

 

Option B. Delirium tremens (DTs). This is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal that typically manifests 48-72 hours after the last drink. It is characterized by altered mental status, agitation, visual hallucinations, and severe autonomic hyperactivity. The presence of tremors alone without the other features makes DTs less likely in this case.

 

Option D. Wernicke's encephalopathy. This is an acute neuropsychiatric syndrome resulting from thiamine deficiency, often related to chronic alcohol use. It is characterized by the triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia. Tremors are not a primary feature of this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classic and most common sign of alcohol withdrawal is tremulousness (coarse tremors). It occurs after 6-8 hours after the last alcohol use. 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 276.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman seeks therapy for depression and low self-esteem. During her sessions, she frequently makes statements like "I'm a complete failure," "Nobody likes me," and "I'll never be able to succeed at anything." Which cognitive distortion is the patient most likely exhibiting?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Overgeneralization

 

Option B:

 

Overgeneralization is the correct answer. The patient is taking isolated instances or experiences and applying them broadly to her life, leading her to believe that she is a complete failure and unlikable in all situations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. All-or-nothing thinking refers to the tendency to view situations, people, or events in black-and-white, absolute terms. This cognitive distortion may contribute to the patient's statements, but overgeneralization is more directly related to her pattern of thought.

 

Option C. Catastrophizing refers to the tendency to imagine and fixate on the worst possible outcomes in any situation. While this cognitive distortion may contribute to her depression, it does not directly relate to her statements.

 

Option D. Emotional reasoning is the cognitive distortion of assuming that because one feels a certain way, it must be true. This distortion is not directly related to the patient's statements.

 

Educational objective:

 

Overgeneralization is taking a single negative event and generalizing it into a broad rule. E.g., I didn't get hired for the job. I'll never get a job. 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 399.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is seeing a therapist for anxiety. During his sessions, he frequently talks about his fear of making a mistake at work and getting fired. He states, "If I make one mistake, it'll be the end of my career, and I'll never find another job." Which cognitive distortion is the patient most likely exhibiting?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Catastrophizing

 

Option C:

 

Catastrophizing is the correct answer. The patient is fixating on the worst possible outcome, imagining that a single mistake would lead to losing his job and being unable to find another one.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. All-or-nothing thinking refers to the tendency to view situations, people, or events in black-and-white, absolute terms. This cognitive distortion could contribute to the patient's anxiety, but it is not the primary distortion in this case.

 

Option B. Overgeneralization involves taking isolated instances or experiences and applying them broadly to one's life. While this cognitive distortion may contribute to the patient's anxiety, it is not the primary distortion in this case.

 

Option D. Emotional reasoning is the cognitive distortion of assuming that because one feels a certain way, it must be true. This distortion is not directly related to the patient's statements.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Catastrophizing is a cognitive distortion characterized by expecting or predicting the worst possible outcome in a situation, often exaggerating potential problems. The patient's fear that a single mistake at work would lead to catastrophic consequences for his career exemplifies this distortion. It involves focusing on the worst-case scenario and exaggerating potential negative outcomes. 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 399.

questions.text: A 23-year-old medical student from Lady Hardinge Medical College is being treated for acrophobia (fear of heights). The treating therapist teaches the student deep breathing techniques for relaxation and then begins exposing the student to heights starting with the first floor, gradually increasing the height while the student uses relaxation techniques during these exposures. Which psychotherapy technique is being used by the therapist?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Systematic desensitization

 

Option B:

 

Systematic desensitization is a type of behavior therapy that combines relaxation techniques with gradual exposure to the feared situation or object. In this case, the therapist teaches the student deep breathing techniques for relaxation and then gradually exposes the student to increasing heights while using the relaxation techniques.

 

Explanation

 

Option A. Therapeutic graded exposure: This option is close but not the most accurate description of the technique being used. Graded exposure involves gradually facing the feared situation, but it does not include relaxation techniques.

 

Option C. Cognitive-behavioral therapy: While cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) is a broad treatment approach that may incorporate exposure and relaxation techniques, it also involves identifying and challenging irrational thoughts and beliefs related to the fear. The description provided focuses specifically on relaxation and exposure, making systematic desensitization a more accurate answer.

 

Option D. Participant modeling: In participant modeling, the therapist models appropriate behavior in the feared situation and then guides the client in practicing the behavior. This option does not accurately describe the technique being used in the scenario, as the therapist is not modeling behavior for the student. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Systematic desensitization is a behavior therapy technique used to treat phobias and involves three main steps: relaxation training, the creation of an anxiety hierarchy, and exposure to the feared stimuli while the individual remains relaxed. It is distinct from other therapeutic approaches like CBT and participant modeling in its specific use of relaxation techniques in conjunction with graded exposure.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 771-772.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male who lives in Delhi avoids using the metro train for travel purposes despite it being both cost and time-effective. On asking the reason for the same, he says that when the metro enters the tunnels, he gets very anxious and feels as if he is trapped and has difficulty breathing. He also reports that he feels the same in crowded metro stations and feels that he won't be able to get out. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Agoraphobia

 

Option A:

 

Agoraphobia is characterized by an intense fear of being in situations where escape might be difficult or help might not be available, such as crowded public places, open spaces, or public transportation. In this case, the patient experiences anxiety in both closed places (tunnels) and crowded places (crowded metro stations), which is consistent with agoraphobia.

 

Explanation

 

Option B. Claustrophobia: Claustrophobia is characterized by an irrational fear of confined spaces. Although the patient experiences anxiety in tunnels, the presence of anxiety in crowded metro stations as well suggests a broader issue, such as agoraphobia.

 

Option C. Social Phobia: Social phobia, also known as social anxiety disorder, is characterized by a fear of social situations where the individual may be exposed to scrutiny by others. The patient's symptoms do not primarily revolve around social situations or the fear of being judged, so this diagnosis is less likely.

 

Option D. Aerophobia: Aerophobia is the fear of flying. The patient's anxiety is related to metro trains and crowded stations, not flying, so this diagnosis is not applicable.

 

Given the patient's anxiety in both closed places (tunnels) and crowded places (crowded metro stations), agoraphobia is the most appropriate diagnosis.

 

Educational objective:

 

Agoraphobia is defined as the fear of places from which escape might be difficult, this includes fear of open spaces, crowded places, enclosed places, traveling alone, and public transport. 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 402.

questions.text: According to the Mental Health Care Act, 2017, any adult can make a legally binding document that expresses the way the person wishes to be treated for a mental illness, which would become applicable if the person loses the capacity to make mental health care or treatment decisions. What is this document called?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Advanced Directive

 

Option A:

 

An Advanced Directive is a legally binding document under the Mental Health Care Act, 2017, in which an adult can specify their preferences regarding the treatment they wish to receive (or not receive) for a mental illness, should they lose the capacity to make informed decisions about their care in the future. This directive helps ensure that the individual's treatment preferences are respected even when they are not in a position to communicate their wishes due to their mental state.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B) Advanced Instructive, C) Advanced Injunctive and D) Advanced Dictetive are not recognized legal documents in the context of mental health care.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Advance directive is a document written by any competent person (except minors) anticipating a period of incompetence. Every person (not a minor) can make an advance directive in which they can mention how they wish to be treated/not treated for a mental illness. It is applicable only if a person loses the capacity to take mental healthcare or treatment decisions. Duty of psychiatrist (or medical officer) to give treatment according to the advance directive. Doctor is not liable in case of unforeseen consequences while following the advance directive.

 

Ref: Forensic Psychiatry in India, Interface of Indian Laws and Mental Health, Page 41-42.

choices.text: Clonazepam plus Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)
Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs) plus Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)
Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs) plus Behavioral Therapy (BT)

questions.text: A 36-year-old homemaker visits her physician complaining of continuous fatigue and frequent pain in her neck and shoulders. Despite her husband's stable and successful job, she is constantly preoccupied with concerns about their financial situation. She is also worried about her children potentially getting injured while playing, even though no such events have taken place. Furthermore, she is anxious about her parents' health as they age, even though they are presently in good health. She has trouble falling asleep, often taking an extended time to do so. All her medical tests are within normal limits. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs) plus Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)

 

Option B:

 

The patient's symptoms, including continuous fatigue, excessive worry about multiple aspects of her life (financial situation, children's safety, parents' health), difficulty falling asleep, and the absence of medical explanations for her symptoms, suggest a diagnosis of Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD). GAD is characterized by excessive anxiety and worry about various events or activities, occurring more days than not for at least six months.

 

The combination of Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs) and Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) is a well-established and effective treatment for GAD. SSRIs are considered first-line pharmacotherapy for GAD due to their efficacy and relatively favorable side effect profile. CBT, a form of psychotherapy, helps patients identify and challenge their anxiety-provoking thoughts and beliefs and develop coping strategies to manage anxiety.

 

Explanation

 

Option A. Clonazepam plus Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT): Clonazepam is a benzodiazepine, which can provide short-term relief from anxiety symptoms but may lead to dependence and is not the best long-term solution. CBT can be helpful, but a combination of clonazepam and CBT is not the optimal choice for this patient.

 

Option C. Clonazepam plus Behavioral Therapy (BT): Although behavioral therapy can be helpful in managing anxiety, CBT is the preferred psychotherapy in the management of GAD. Also, clonazepam is not the best choice for long-term treatment due to the risk of dependence.

 

Option D. Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs) plus Behavioral Therapy (BT): While SSRIs are effective for treating anxiety and BT can be helpful, the combination of SSRIs and CBT has been shown to be more effective in managing generalized anxiety disorder than SSRIs and BT alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD), a combination of Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs) and Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) is an effective treatment approach. SSRIs address the neurochemical aspects of anxiety, while CBT helps patients manage their anxious thoughts and behaviors through cognitive restructuring and behavioral interventions.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 405.

choices.text: Recent placement of a coronary artery stent

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with treatment-resistant depressive disorder is being evaluated for electroconvulsive therapy (ECT). The patient’s psychiatrist is considering her medical history to identify any potential contraindications to ECT. Which of the following is an absolute contraindication to proceeding with ECT?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) None of the above

 

Option D:

 

Given that none of the conditions listed are absolute contraindications to ECT, the correct answer is D) None of the above.

 

Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is considered a safe and effective treatment option for various psychiatric disorders, especially when other treatments have failed. While certain medical conditions can increase the risks associated with ECT, it does not mean that ECT is absolutely contraindicated.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Recent placement of a coronary artery stent: This condition necessitates a careful evaluation and optimization of the patient’s cardiac status before ECT. However, with adequate precautions and monitoring, patients with a recent coronary artery stent can safely undergo ECT.

 

Option B. Space-occupying brain lesion: Although a space-occupying brain lesion does pose increased risks during ECT due to the potential for raised intracranial pressure, it is not considered an absolute contraindication. With proper evaluation, modification of ECT technique, and neurosurgical consultation if necessary, ECT can still be performed safely in some cases.

 

Option C. Pregnancy: ECT is generally considered safe during pregnancy, particularly when the risks of untreated psychiatric illness to both the mother and the fetus are high. Appropriate precautions, such as proper positioning and oxygenation, are essential to minimize risks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

There is no absolute contraindication for ECT. 

 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 734-735.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male with a history of chronic alcohol use presents to the emergency department with complaints of feeling shaky, increased irritability, and difficulty sleeping for the past 24 hours. He reports stopping his alcohol consumption 2 days ago. On examination, he is found to be tremulous. Which of the following is a clinical feature of uncomplicated alcohol withdrawal?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Auditory hallucinations.

 

Option A:

 

Alcohol withdrawal syndrome is a clinical manifestation seen in individuals with chronic alcohol use who suddenly decrease or stop their alcohol consumption. The withdrawal state can be uncomplicated, which includes alcohol withdrawal tremors and alcohol withdrawal with perceptual disturbances and complicated, which includes alcohol withdrawal seizures and alcohol withdrawal delirium (delirium tremens). Alcohol withdrawal with perceptual disturbances is a type of uncomplicated alcohol withdrawal and is characterized by auditory (and sometimes visual) hallucinations. This typically occurs within 12-24 hours of the last drink. The patient remains oriented and has a clear sensorium during this period.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Pinpoint pupils. This is incorrect. Pinpoint pupils are not a feature of alcohol withdrawal but can be seen in opioid overdose.

 

Option C. Hyporeflexia. This is incorrect. Alcohol withdrawal is associated with autonomic hyperactivity and increased reflexes, not decreased reflexes. 

 

Option D. Fluctuating levels of consciousness. This is incorrect. Fluctuating levels of consciousness are not typically seen in uncomplicated alcohol withdrawal. However, it can be a feature of delirium tremens, a severe form of alcohol withdrawal, but it is often accompanied by severe agitation, and tachycardia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Alcohol withdrawal with perceptual disturbances refers to hallucinations in the absence of any disturbances of consciousness. Usually, auditory hallucinations are present. It occurs 12-24 hours after the last alcohol drink.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 276.

questions.text: A 31-year-old patient presents to the psychiatry outpatient department, stating, "Doctor, I feel like a horrible person and am ashamed of myself. I keep having inappropriate thoughts about God, and despite my attempts to avoid these thoughts, I can't control them. I don't understand why I think this way. I spend hours each day apologizing to God, fearing divine punishment." What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder

 

Option C:

 

The patient's symptoms, including persistent and unwanted thoughts about God (obsessions) and repetitive behavior like apologizing (compulsions), are consistent with a diagnosis of Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Generalized Anxiety Disorder: This diagnosis involves excessive anxiety and worry about various aspects of life, occurring for at least six months. Although the patient is experiencing anxiety, the primary concern revolves around intrusive thoughts about God and the compulsive behavior of apologizing. These symptoms are more consistent with OCD.

 

Option B. Impulse Control Disorder: Impulse control disorders involve a failure to resist an urge to engage in a harmful behavior. The patient's symptoms do not match this diagnosis, as the primary issue is the presence of intrusive thoughts and compulsive actions, which are characteristic of OCD.

 

Option D. Major Depressive Disorder: Although the patient expresses negative feelings about themselves, the primary concern is the intrusive thoughts and compulsive behavior. The symptoms described are more indicative of OCD than Major Depressive Disorder. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The patient's presentation of uncontrollable, inappropriate thoughts about God and the compulsive behavior of apologizing for hours each day to avoid feared divine punishment is consistent with Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD). OCD is characterized by obsessions (intrusive, distressing thoughts or images) and compulsions (repetitive behaviors aimed at neutralizing the distress caused by the obsessions). 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 415.

choices.text: Alcohol withdrawal with perceptual disturbances

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of 2 days of increasing confusion and restlessness. She reports that he has been consuming alcohol for the past 20 years and typically drinks a fifth of vodka daily. However, he abruptly stopped drinking 3 days ago following a family intervention. On physical examination, his temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), blood pressure is 160/95 mmHg, pulse is 115/min, and respirations are 22/min. The patient appears anxious and disoriented to time and place. He becomes frightened as he describes snakes crawling on the walls of the examination room. His hands reveal a coarse tremor, and he has profuse diaphoresis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Delirium tremens

 

Option B:

 

The patient's clinical presentation is indicative of delirium tremens (DTs), a severe form of alcohol withdrawal. Key features supporting this diagnosis include his history of chronic alcohol use, the abrupt cessation of alcohol consumption, and the onset of symptoms within a few days of stopping drinking. The clinical manifestations of DTs include confusion, disorientation, agitation, fever, hypertension, tachycardia, tremors, profuse sweating, and hallucinations (often visual). The description of seeing snakes on the walls is a classic presentation of visual hallucinations associated with DTs.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alcohol withdrawal with perceptual disturbances: While this condition involves hallucinations and occur during alcohol withdrawal, DTs are characterized by more severe symptoms, including autonomic instability (elevated heart rate and blood pressure, fever) and confusion, which are evident in this case.

 

Option C. Wernicke encephalopathy: Wernicke encephalopathy, caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, presents with the classic triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia. Although confusion is present, the lack of ophthalmoplegia and ataxia makes this diagnosis less likely.

 

Option D. Brief psychotic disorder: This disorder involves sudden onset of psychotic symptoms, such as hallucinations or delusions, lasting less than a month. However, in the context of recent alcohol withdrawal and the presence of other signs of DTs, delirium tremens is the more likely diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delirium Tremens (DTs) (alcohol withdrawal delirium) is a medical emergency and if untreated the mortality rate is around 20%. The symptoms and signs include disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucination (most commonly visual), coarse tremors, and autonomic hyperactivity. It usually occurs after 48-72 hours of the last alcohol intake or reduction in the amount of alcohol use. 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 276-277.

choices.text: Obsessive-compulsive and related disorders
Anxiety and fear-related disorders

questions.text: A 28-year-old female is brought to the psychiatrist by her mother. The mother complains that her daughter continuously collects various useless items and never discards anything. The mother is frustrated because the entire house is cluttered as a result. The patient expresses a desire to throw away the useless items but fears losing something she may need later. The patient's condition belongs to which diagnostic category?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Obsessive-compulsive and related disorders

 

Option B:

 

The patient's behavior of continuously collecting various items, reluctance to discard possessions due to a fear of needing them later, and resulting significant clutter describes symptoms of Hoarding Disorder. Hoarding Disorder is characterized by persistent difficulty discarding or parting with possessions, regardless of their actual value, due to a perceived need to save the items and distress associated with discarding them. This behavior leads to cluttered living areas and significant distress or impairment in functioning. Hoarding Disorder is classified under Obsessive-Compulsive and Related Disorders in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, 5th Edition (DSM-5).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Impulse control disorder involves difficulty in resisting the urge to perform an act that could be harmful to oneself or others, such as pyromania (setting fires) or kleptomania (stealing). The patient's behavior does not indicate an impulse to perform potentially harmful acts, but rather a difficulty in discarding possessions due to fear of needing them later.

 

Option C. Personality disorders are characterized by enduring patterns of inner experience and behavior that deviate markedly from the expectations of the individual's culture, are pervasive and inflexible, and lead to distress or impairment. While hoarding can be a feature of certain personality disorders (such as obsessive-compulsive personality disorder), the specific description of distress related to the inability to discard items and fear of losing something needed later is more indicative of Hoarding Disorder.

 

Option D. Anxiety and fear-related disorders include conditions where anxiety or fear is the predominant feature, such as generalized anxiety disorder, panic disorder, and phobias. While anxiety can be a component of Hoarding Disorder, particularly anxiety about discarding items, the specific symptoms described are more characteristic of an obsessive-compulsive and related disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obsessive-compulsive and related disorders in DSM-5:

 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 419.

choices.text: Body-focused repetitive behavior disorder

questions.text: A 27-year-old female presents to the psychiatrist with concerns about her appearance. She reports that she believes her nose is severely deformed and that everyone around her is constantly staring at it. Her family and friends have reassured her multiple times that her nose appears normal, but she remains convinced that it is a significant defect. She spends hours each day looking in the mirror, comparing her nose to pictures of others, and researching surgical options. She has even stopped attending social events due to her fear of being judged. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Body dysmorphic disorder

 

Option A:

 

The patient's preoccupation with a perceived defect in her appearance, despite reassurances from others, presence of repetitive behaviours such as looking in mirror along with the significant distress and impairment in her daily functioning, are consistent with the diagnosis of body dysmorphic disorder.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Body-focused repetitive behavior disorder: This disorder is characterized by recurrent behaviors focused on one's body, such as hair-pulling (trichotillomania), or skin-picking (excoriation). The patient's symptoms do not align with this disorder, as her primary concern is a perceived defect in her appearance rather than engaging in repetitive behaviors.

 

Option C. Delusional disorder: Delusional disorder involves the presence of one or more delusions that persist for at least one month, without other psychotic symptoms. This patient presents with a preoccupations followed by repetitive behaviours in relation to that preoccupation, this goes more in favour of body dysmorphic disorder. In case the patient develops a firm, fixed belief, even then, the diagnosis of body dysmorphic disorder with absent insight/delusional belief will be favoured over the diagnosis of delusional disorder

 

Option D. Social anxiety disorder: Social anxiety disorder is characterized by a persistent fear of social situations due to concerns about being judged or humiliated. While the patient does avoid social events, her avoidance is primarily driven by her perceived appearance defect, making body dysmorphic disorder the more accurate diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Body Dysmorphic Disorder (BDD) is characterized by the preoccupation with an imagined defect in body appearance. In case, a slight physical anomaly is present, the patient's concern for the same is exaggerated. The location of the imagined defect is usually hair, nose and skin.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 416.

choices.text: Modulation of brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF)

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with a history of severe depression is undergoing a series of electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) sessions. A medical student rotating in the psychiatry department is interested in understanding the mechanism of action of ECT. Which of the following best describes the primary mechanism by which ECT exerts its therapeutic effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Modulation of brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF)

 

Option C:

 

Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is a well-established treatment for severe depression, particularly with high suicidal risk and certain other mental health conditions. The primary mechanism by which ECT exerts its therapeutic effects is not fully understood, but it is believed to involve several neurobiological changes. One key mechanism is thought to be the modulation of brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF). BDNF is a protein that plays a crucial role in the growth, maintenance, and survival of neurons. It also contributes to neuroplasticity, which is the brain's ability to reorganize itself by forming new neural connections. ECT has been shown to increase BDNF levels, which could lead to improved mood and cognitive function.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Enhancement of GABAergic transmission: While ECT does influence GABAergic transmission, this is not considered its primary mechanism of therapeutic action. GABA is the main inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brain, and its enhancement typically has calming effects.

 

Option B. Inhibition of monoamine oxidase: Monoamine oxidase inhibitors are a class of antidepressants that work by preventing the breakdown of monoamine neurotransmitters. ECT does increase the levels of monoamines (serotonin, norepinephrine, and dopamine) in the brain, but it does not do so by inhibiting monoamine oxidase.

 

Option D. Suppression of hippocampal neurogenesis: This option is incorrect, as ECT has actually been shown to promote hippocampal neurogenesis (the production of new neurons in the hippocampus), which is believed to contribute to its antidepressant effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 730-731.

choices.text: Succinylcholine for seizure induction and methohexital for muscle relaxation
Succinylcholine for muscle relaxation and methohexital for anesthesia
Succinylcholine for anesthesia and methohexital for seizure induction
Succinylcholine for seizure augmentation and methohexital for muscle relaxation

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with severe refractory depression is scheduled to undergo electroconvulsive therapy (ECT). During the pre-procedure briefing, the anesthesiologist explains the roles of different medications used during ECT. Which of the following best describes the roles of succinylcholine and methohexital in ECT?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Succinylcholine for muscle relaxation and methohexital for anesthesia

 

Option B:

 

In electroconvulsive therapy (ECT), the roles of succinylcholine and methohexital are as follows:

 

  • Succinylcholine: This medication is a depolarizing muscle relaxant. It is used during ECT to relax muscles and minimize muscular contractions associated with the seizure. By doing so, it helps reduce the risk of musculoskeletal injuries that can be caused by the convulsions during ECT.
  • Methohexital: Methohexital is a short-acting barbiturate anesthetic. It is used to induce anesthesia prior to ECT. Its role is to ensure that the patient is unconscious and does not experience pain or discomfort during the procedure.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Succinylcholine for seizure induction and methohexital for muscle relaxation: This is incorrect. Succinylcholine does not induce seizures; it is used for muscle relaxation. Methohexital is an anesthetic, not a muscle relaxant.

 

Option C. Succinylcholine for anesthesia and methohexital for seizure induction: This is incorrect. Succinylcholine is a muscle relaxant, not an anesthetic. Methohexital provides anesthesia, not seizure induction.

 

Option D. Succinylcholine for seizure augmentation and methohexital for muscle relaxation: This is incorrect. Succinylcholine is used for muscle relaxation, and methohexital is used for anesthesia. Neither is used for seizure augmentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 732-733.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman diagnosed with major depressive disorder is resistant to pharmacological treatments. Her psychiatrist discusses the option of electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) to manage her symptoms. Given her medical history, the psychiatrist wishes to use modified ECT. The anesthesiologist is consulted to determine the best anesthetic agent for the procedure. Which of the following is the anesthetic agent of choice in modified ECT?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thiopentone

 

Option A:

 

For modified electroconvulsive therapy (ECT), the most commonly used anesthetic agent is Thiopentone. It provides rapid induction and a short duration of action, making it ideal for ECT, which is a brief procedure.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Ketamine: While ketamine might have an antidepressant effect, but it can increase blood pressure and intraocular pressure, making it less ideal for ECT. 

 

Option C. Midazolam: Midazolam is a benzodiazepine used for sedation and anxiolysis. It is not commonly used as the primary anesthetic agent in ECT because benzodiazepines can suppress seizure activity, which is counterproductive in ECT.

 

Option D. Halothane: Halothane is an inhalational anesthetic agent not typically used in ECT. Inhalational agents are generally avoided in ECT due to their potential to suppress seizure activity and because the procedure is brief and does not require prolonged anesthesia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anesthetic agent of choice for ECT is methohexital. If methohexital is not in the options, thiopentone becomes the better choice. 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 732.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is undergoing psychotherapy for depression. During the sessions, she often remarks how her therapist reminds her of her strict father, who was demanding and critical. She expresses feelings of resentment and becomes increasingly hostile toward the therapist, accusing him of being judgmental, even when he offers neutral observations. This phenomenon is best described as:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Transference.

 

Option D:

 

Transference is a phenomenon in psychotherapy where a patient redirects emotions and feelings, often unconscious, from one person to another, particularly in the context of a therapist-patient relationship. In this case, the patient is transferring feelings, perceptions, and expectations from her relationship with her strict and demanding father onto her therapist. This can manifest as irrational feelings and behaviors that are incongruent with the actual relationship with the therapist. It is a common occurrence in psychotherapy and can be used therapeutically to understand a patient's interpersonal patterns and past influences.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Countertransference: This refers to the therapist's emotional response to the patient. It's the therapist's own reenactment of unconscious feelings or experiences from their past.

 

Option B. Resistance: In psychoanalytic theory, resistance is the patient's unconscious avoidance of their anxiety-producing thoughts and feelings. It's an obstacle in therapy, as it hampers the patient's ability to gain insight and work through their issues.

 

Option C. Projection: Projection is a defense mechanism where a person attributes their own unacceptable thoughts, feelings, or motives to another person. It does not capture the full relational dynamic playing out between the patient and therapist, as described in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transference refers to feeling that the patient develops for the doctor; it’s a combination of the feelings patient had for important figures from the past and the real feeling for the clinician. 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 1069.

choices.text: It is not a treatment for dysthymic disorder
It is used to treat complex partial seizure
Use for those major depressive patients not responding to medical therapy
Memory impairment is a side effect

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of major depressive disorder is being considered for electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) after failing multiple lines of pharmacological treatments. His family, concerned about potential side effects and the indications for ECT, seeks a consultation. Which of the following statements about ECT is NOT true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is used to treat complex partial seizure

 

Option B:

 

Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is not used to treat complex partial seizures. ECT involves inducing controlled seizures through the application of electrical currents to the brain while the patient is under anesthesia. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. It is not a treatment for dysthymic disorder: This statement is true. ECT is typically reserved for severe cases of major depressive disorder, particularly those that are treatment-resistant. Dysthymia, being a chronic but less severe form of depression, is not usually treated with ECT.

 

Option C. It is used for major depressive patients not responding to medical therapy: This is true. ECT is often considered when patients with major depressive disorder do not respond to standard antidepressant medications or when a rapid response is needed due to the severity of the depression.

 

Option D. Memory impairment is a side effect: This is true. Memory impairment is a known side effect of ECT. Although these effects are generally temporary, some patients may experience more persistent memory issues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 731.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents to the psychiatric clinic with complaints of repetitive hand washing and constant thoughts of contamination. These rituals and thoughts are consuming a significant portion of her daily life, hindering work efficiency and personal relationships. In discussing the symptoms, she mentions trying to push away thoughts about dirt and germs deliberately but ends up focusing on them even more. The psychiatrist aims to identify the defense mechanisms contributing to this condition. Which defense mechanism is not typically associated with OCD?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Suppression 

 

Option B:

 

Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) often involves certain defense mechanisms, but not all defense mechanisms are directly linked to its development. 

 

Suppression refers to the conscious effort to push away distressing thoughts or feelings. While it might be seen in individuals as a general defense mechanism, it isn’t specifically tied to the development of OCD.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Displacement involves diverting emotions or impulses to a neutral or less threatening object or situation. It can manifest in OCD when a person might displace their aggressive or harmful impulses into compulsive actions like cleaning.

 

Option C.  Isolation of affect is a mechanism where one might separate their feelings from ideas or events. In OCD, an individual may recognize their obsessions as senseless but are unable to control the distress associated with them.

 

Option D. Undoing is common in OCD, where the individual tries to "undo" an unacceptable thought or wish by performing a ritualistic behavior.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

 

Ref: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page 97.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset palpitations, shortness of breath, and a feeling of impending doom. She describes the episode as starting abruptly while watching television, with no identifiable trigger. She also reports feeling dizzy, trembling, and fearing that she was having a heart attack or "going crazy". The entire episode lasted about 20 minutes. Her vital signs in the ED are stable, her ECG shows normal sinus rhythm, and her blood workup, including troponins, is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Panic attack

 

Option D: 

 

The patient's presentation is consistent with a panic attack. Key features in this case that point to a panic attack are the sudden onset, the lack of an identifiable trigger, and the diverse range of symptoms including palpitations, shortness of breath, trembling, and intense fear.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Myocardial infarction: While symptoms like chest pain and shortness of breath are associated with heart attacks, the patient's young age, lack of risk factors, and normal troponins and ECG make this diagnosis less likely.

 

Option B: Asthma exacerbation: Asthma can cause shortness of breath and chest tightness, but it would not explain the intense fear, trembling, or feeling of impending doom.

 

Option C: Hypoglycemia: Low blood sugar can cause symptoms like trembling, palpitations, and dizziness. However, the intense fear and feeling of impending doom are more typical of a panic attack.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A panic attack is an acute attack of intense anxiety accompanied by a feeling of impending doom. The symptoms during the panic attack usually involve sudden onset of palpitations, chest pain, choking sensations, dizziness, and feelings of unreality (depersonalization or derealization). Along with these physical symptoms, there is also a fear of dying, losing control or going mad. For immediate relief from panic attacks, benzodiazepines are preferred. 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 402.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with complaints of recurrent episodes of intense fear that come on suddenly and peak within minutes. She describes these episodes as feeling like she's "going to die" or "losing control." During these attacks, she experiences palpitations, trembling, shortness of breath, and a fear of impending doom. She notes that these attacks occur unpredictably and can even wake her from sleep. Because of these episodes, she has started avoiding certain situations, including driving and going to crowded places, fearing that an episode might occur and she won't be able to escape or get help. She denies any recent caffeine intake, drug use, or medications. She has no history of trauma or significant medical conditions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Panic disorder with agoraphobia.

 

Option B:

 

The patient's presentation of sudden episodes of intense fear that peak within minutes and are accompanied by physical symptoms such as palpitations, trembling, and shortness of breath is consistent with panic attacks. When these attacks are recurrent and associated with a persistent concern or behaviour change related to the attacks, the diagnosis is panic disorder. Furthermore, the patient's avoidance of certain situations due to a fear of being unable to escape or obtain help during a panic attack indicates agoraphobia. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Generalized anxiety disorder is characterized by excessive and persistent worry about a variety of topics but lacks the sudden, intense panic attacks described.

 

Option C: Post-traumatic stress disorder develops following a traumatic event and involves re-experiencing the trauma, avoidance of reminders, negative alterations in mood, and increased arousal.

 

Option D: Social anxiety disorder involves a marked fear of one or more social or performance situations where the individual is exposed to unfamiliar people or to possible scrutiny by others.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Panic disorder is characterized by recurrent and unexpected panic attacks with anticipatory anxiety. Patients may start ‘avoiding’ situations that they link with the panic attack. Agoraphobia is defined as the fear of places from which escape might be difficult, this includes fear of open spaces, crowded places, enclosed places, traveling alone, and public transport. Treatment includes a combination of pharmacotherapy [benzodiazepines for short term and SSRIs for long term] and psychotherapy [CBT, relaxation techniques] is preferred. 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 402.

choices.text: Can give consent for admission on behalf of the patient, even if the patient is competent
Can only give consent for admission if the patient is found incompetent
Cannot give consent for admission under any circumstance
Can override the patient’s decision for admission, regardless of the patient’s competence

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of bipolar disorder is being admitted to a psychiatric facility for a manic episode. She is not willing to consent to the admission, stating she does not believe she needs treatment. Her family is concerned about her safety and well-being. According to the Mental Healthcare Act of 2017, a nominated representative may play a role in this scenario. Which of the following statements best describes the role of a nominated representative in this context?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Can only give consent for admission if the patient is found incompetent

 

Option B:

 

According to the Mental Healthcare Act of 2017, a nominated representative may play a significant role in the treatment of a person with a mental illness, in cases where the person is unable or deemed incompetent to make informed decisions about their own care. In this context: a nominated representative can only give consent for admission if the patient is found incompetent. This means that the patient lacks the capacity to understand the nature and purpose of the decisions being made about their treatment or is unable to communicate their decisions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Can give consent for admission on behalf of the patient, even if the patient is competent: This is not accurate. If the patient is competent and able to make informed decisions, their consent is required. The nominated representative cannot override the decision of a competent patient.

 

Option C. Cannot give consent for admission under any circumstance: This is incorrect. The nominated representative can give consent, but only in situations where the patient is found to be incompetent.

 

Option D. Can override the patient’s decision for admission, regardless of the patient’s competence: This is incorrect. The primary consideration is the patient's capacity to make informed decisions. A nominated representative's role is to assist in the decision-making process, particularly when the patient is unable to make decisions due to their mental condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Forensic Psychiatry in India, Interface of Indian Laws and Mental Health, Page 46.

choices.text: A-3, B-4, C-1, D-2
A-4, B-3, C-1, D-2
A-3, B-4, C-2, D-1
A-2, B-1, C-3, D-4

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-3, B-4, C-2, D-1

 

Explanation:

 

"State of emotional and physical exhaustion caused by prolonged stress, relieved after relaxation" perfectly describes burnout. So, C matches with 2.

 

Depression: “Difficult to diagnose due to the shell of physician’s pride" would suggest that physicians might not show or express their symptoms due to professional pride. So, A matches with 3.

 

Suicide: "Women physicians, substance abuse, relationship troubles" could be potential risk factors or associated factors. So, B matches with 4.

 

Overthinking: "The feeling goes away as soon as you leave the hospital" does not clearly correlate with overthinking, but given the other matches, this seems the closest fit. So, D matches with 1.

 

So, the correct matching would be:

 

A) A-3, B-4, C-2, D-1.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 447, 764.

questions.text: The following image is associated with:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Personality test

 

Option C:

 

The image shown is an example of an inkblot, which is most commonly associated with the Rorschach test, a type of projective personality test. In this test, individuals are shown a series of inkblots and asked to describe what they see. The interpretation of the inkblots is thought to reveal aspects of the person's personality, including underlying thought patterns, emotions, and potential internal conflicts or concerns. The Rorschach test is used by psychologists as a tool for psychological evaluation and assessment.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Intelligence test is not accurate as Rorschach inkblot tests are not designed to measure intelligence.

 

Option B. Creativity test although inkblot tests can provide insights into a person's thought processes and imagination, they aren't specifically designed to measure creativity.

 

Option D. Neuroticism is a specific personality trait, and while the Rorschach test may provide insights into various personality traits, the test itself is not exclusively associated with neuroticism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rorschach inkblot test is a projective psychological test primarily used for personality assessment.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 58-59.

choices.text: Schizoaffective disorder in mania

questions.text: A 16-year-old female patient presents to the clinic with an array of concerning behaviours observed over the past week. Her parents report that she has been unusually overly friendly, even with strangers, and she has been speaking rapidly and jumping from topic to topic in a way that is hard to follow. They have also noticed an unusually elevated mood and an increase in her expression of sexual desires. They are unsure of how to handle these changes and are seeking help. Based on the clinical findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mania

 

Option A:

 

In this scenario, the patient's overfamiliarity, flight of ideas, elevated mood, and increased sexual desire all point towards a manic episode. Mania is characterized by elevated or irritable mood, increased energy or activity, and other symptoms such as inflated self-esteem, decreased need for sleep, and distractibility.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Schizoaffective disorder in mania: While the patient exhibits features of mania, there is no mention of symptoms characteristic of schizophrenia, such as delusions or hallucinations, which are necessary for a diagnosis of schizoaffective disorder.

 

Option C: Hypomania: Hypomania is similar to mania but less severe; it does not cause significant impairment in social or occupational functioning. The behaviors described seem too extreme for hypomania.

 

Option D: Cyclothymia: This is a chronic mood disorder characterized by numerous periods of hypomanic symptoms and periods of depressive symptoms lasting for at least 2 years. The symptoms are not severe enough to meet the criteria for a hypomanic episode and a major depressive episode.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical presentation described is indicative of a manic episode, characterized by an abnormally elevated mood, increased sociability, rapid and disorganized speech, and increased sexual desires. These symptoms are more severe than those seen in hypomania or cyclothymia and lack the psychotic features required for schizoaffective disorder.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 365.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a known diagnosis of bipolar disorder has been on lithium maintenance therapy for several years. During her recent routine check-up, her serum lithium level was found to be significantly elevated compared to her previous levels. She mentioned starting a new medication a few weeks ago. Which of the following medications could explain the rise in her lithium level?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) NSAIDs

 

Option C:

 

Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) can lead to an increase in serum lithium levels. This interaction occurs because NSAIDs reduce the renal clearance of lithium, leading to elevated levels in the blood. Patients on lithium therapy are typically advised to use NSAIDs cautiously or opt for alternative pain relievers to avoid this interaction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Carbamazepine: It does not typically cause an increase in lithium levels.

 

Option B: Metoclopramide: This medication, used primarily for nausea and gastroparesis, does not have a significant interaction with lithium in terms of altering lithium levels.

 

Option D: Haloperidol: It does not typically affect lithium levels significantly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drugs which increase the levels of Lithium include: 

 

  1. ACE inhibitors
  2. Thiazide diuretics
  3. NSAIDs

 

Ref: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 254.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male with a history of mood fluctuations has been recently initiated on lithium therapy for his bipolar disorder. Given the known systemic effects of this medication, his psychiatrist emphasizes the importance of periodic laboratory monitoring. Which of the following blood tests should be prioritized for consistent biannual assessment due to its potential alteration by lithium?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) TSH

 

Option B:

 

When a patient is on lithium therapy, periodic monitoring of thyroid function, particularly thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), is important due to lithium's potential impact on thyroid function. Lithium can cause hypothyroidism by interfering with thyroid hormone synthesis and release. Consequently, monitoring TSH levels biannually is a crucial aspect of managing patients on long-term lithium therapy. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: T3RU (Triiodothyronine Resin Uptake): It is not the primary test chosen to monitor lithium-associated thyroid dysfunction.

 

Option C: Total bilirubin: Lithium does not generally have significant effects on liver function tests like bilirubin.

 

Option D: CBC (Complete Blood Count): While lithium can cause leukocytosis, CBC is not included in the biannual tests conducted during treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pre-treatment tests with Lithium include serum creatinine, TSH, ECG and pregnancy test (in females). On treatment monitoring includes serum Lithium levels, serum creatinine, and TSH every 6 months. 

 

Ref: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 251.

choices.text: Administration of normal saline IV
Administration of benztropine IM

questions.text: A 23-year-old male, with a known history of bipolar disorder, is brought into the emergency department by his roommate who found him unconscious next to an empty bottle of lithium pills. On examination, the patient is lethargic and responding minimally to painful stimuli. His vitals reveal mild bradycardia, and initial labs show a lithium level of 4.5 meq/L. Additionally, his urine output is markedly diminished, registering at about 15 mL/hr. Given these findings, what is the most immediate therapeutic intervention necessary for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Emergency dialysis

 

Option B:

 

The patient has severe lithium toxicity, evidenced by his high serum lithium level (4.5 meq/L) and neurological and renal impairment. Emergency dialysis is vital in cases of high lithium concentrations combined with acute kidney injury and significant neurological symptoms.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Administration of normal saline IV is beneficial for mild to moderate lithium toxicity, but inadequate for this severity.

 

Option C: Administration of benztropine IM is for extrapyramidal symptoms from antipsychotics, not relevant here.

 

Option D: Cardiac monitoring is essential in overdose scenarios but isn't the primary intervention needed given the lithium toxicity and renal impairment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Signs and symptoms of Lithium toxicity:

 

 

Ref: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 250-251.

choices.text: Alcohol withdrawal with perceptual disturbances

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic alcohol use undergoes surgery for acute appendicitis. Post-operatively, the patient exhibits confusion and reports visual hallucinations of snakes in the ward. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Delirium tremens  

 

Option B:

 

The patient's presentation, with a history of chronic alcohol use, recent surgery, and the onset of confusion and vivid visual hallucinations post-operatively, is suggestive of delirium tremens (DTs). DTs is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal that typically present 48-72 hours after the last drink and can be precipitated by acute illness, surgery, or trauma. The key features include disturbances of consciousness, disorientation, hallucinations (usually visual, like the snakes), agitation, and autonomic hyperactivity. .

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alcohol withdrawal with perceptual disturbances: While this condition also involves hallucinations during withdrawal, it is typically less severe than DTs and doesn't usually include the marked confusion characteristic of DTs.

 

Option C. Wernicke’s encephalopathy: Wernicke's encephalopathy is an acute neurologic condition caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, commonly seen in chronic alcohol users. It is characterized by the classic triad of global confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia. While confusion is present, the absence of ophthalmoplegia and ataxia makes this less likely.

 

Option D. Korsakoff syndrome: Korsakoff syndrome is a chronic memory disorder caused by severe thiamine deficiency. It is characterized by anterograde and retrograde amnesia and confabulation. It follows an episode of Wernicke’s encephalopathy but does not present with acute confusion and hallucinations as described in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 276-277.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother due to concerns regarding his academic performance and behaviour at school. The teacher reports that the child often seems distracted, frequently leaves his seat, and has difficulty waiting his turn in group activities. The psychiatrist, suspecting ADHD, contemplates the various pharmacological options available. In considering medications, the paediatrician recalls that one of the following drugs is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor. Which drug is it?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atomoxetine

 

Option B:

 

Atomoxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (NRI) and is used for the treatment of Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD). Unlike stimulant medications such as methylphenidate and amphetamines, atomoxetine works by selectively inhibiting the reuptake of norepinephrine, a neurotransmitter associated with attention and impulsivity. Atomoxetine is particularly useful in patients with ADHD who may not respond well to stimulants, have a history of substance abuse, or have certain comorbid conditions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Methylphenidate: Methylphenidate is a stimulant medication that primarily works by increasing the levels of dopamine and norepinephrine in the brain, but it is not classified as a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor.

 

Option C.  Clonidine: Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist. It is used as a second-line treatment for ADHD. It is not an NRI.

 

Option D. Modafinil: Modafinil is another stimulant used primarily for conditions like narcolepsy. It is not an NRI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atomoxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor used for the treatment of ADHD. It is a non-stimulant medication option for patients with ADHD, especially those who may not be suitable candidates for stimulant medications.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 136-137.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy has been diagnosed with an intellectual disability and is currently being assessed to determine the most appropriate educational placement. He has significant difficulties in verbal and non-verbal communication, requires constant supervision for personal care, and has not developed any functional academic skills. His engagement in social interactions is limited, and he shows a preference for solitary activities. Based on his adaptive functioning and educational needs, what is the most likely severity of his intellectual disability?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Severe

 

Option C:

 

The description of the 15-year-old boy indicates significant limitations in several areas of functioning. His difficulties in verbal and non-verbal communication, need for constant supervision in personal care, with lack of functional academic skills, and limited social interactions suggest a level of impairment beyond mild or moderate intellectual disability.

 

Severe ID: Correct. Individuals may acquire limited communication skills and need support for      daily living activities. Academic skills are minimal to none, and they require extensive support. While constant supervision for personal care, doesn't necessarily indicate he needs continuous supervision for all aspects of life or life support which is seen in profound ID

 

The severity of intellectual disability (ID) is primarily determined by adaptive functioning in three domains: conceptual, social, and practical. The level of support required in daily life activities, communication, and social interactions are key indicators of the severity of ID.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Mild ID: Incorrect. Individuals with mild ID can develop social and vocational skills and may achieve up to 6th-grade academic skills. They may live independently with community and social support.

 

Option B. Moderate ID: Incorrect. Individuals may learn basic self-care skills and practical skills for daily living. They may achieve up to 2nd-grade academic skills and require moderate support.

 

Option D. Profound ID: Incorrect. Individuals have pervasive impairments and need a caregiver for all daily living activities. They may have some ability to respond to physical and social activities but require constant, high-level support.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Individuals with severe intellectual disability exhibit profound deficits in communication and social skills, require extensive support in some daily living activities, and have minimal to no functional academic skills.

choices.text: Depression can increase the risk of myocardial infarction.
Experiencing a myocardial infarction can predispose to depression.
SSRIs can be prescribed safely after a myocardial infarction to address depressive symptoms.
Only cognitive behavioral therapy should be recommended after myocardial infarction.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man, recently hospitalized for a myocardial infarction, is seen in the cardiology clinic for follow-up. He reports feeling persistently sad, fatigued and has lost interest in activities he previously enjoyed. He admits to feeling "worthless" since his hospitalization. His cardiologist wants to address his mood symptoms and is considering the next steps in management. Which of the following statements regarding his condition and potential interventions is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Only cognitive behavioral therapy should be recommended after myocardial infarction.

 

Option D:

 

This patient's symptoms of persistent sadness, fatigue, anhedonia, and feelings of worthlessness suggest he is suffering from depression following his myocardial infarction (MI). 

 

The statement that "Only cognitive behavioral therapy should be recommended after myocardial infarction" is false. While cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is a valuable treatment for depression and can be used in patients following a myocardial infarction (MI), it is not the only option for managing depressive symptoms in this population. Antidepressant medications, particularly selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), are also considered safe and effective in treating depression in patients who have experienced an MI.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Depression can increase the risk of myocardial infarction: This is true. Depression is associated with an increased risk of coronary artery disease and subsequent MI.

 

Option B: Experiencing a myocardial infarction can predispose to depression: This is also true. The experience of having an MI can be psychologically traumatic, and the subsequent lifestyle changes and health concerns can contribute to the development of depression.

 

Option C: SSRIs can be prescribed safely after a myocardial infarction to address depressive symptoms: This is true. SSRIs are generally considered safe in patients with heart disease and can be used to treat depression following an MI. They are preferred over other antidepressant classes like tricyclic antidepressants, which can have adverse cardiac effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Depression is common after a myocardial infarction and can affect recovery and outcomes. Both pharmacological (e.g., SSRIs) and non-pharmacological (e.g., CBT) interventions can be effective in treating post-MI depression.

 

Ref: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 386.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male is undergoing a sleep study to evaluate his sleep patterns. The EEG tracing obtained during the study is shown below. This EEG pattern is most indicative of which stage of sleep?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stage 2 NREM Sleep

 

Option C:

 

The EEG pattern shown in the image is indicative of sleep spindles, which are characteristic of stage 2 non-REM (NREM) sleep. Stage 2 NREM sleep accounts for the maximum duration of all sleep stages and it is characterized by the presence of sleep spindles (bursts of regular waves, 13-15 Hz, 50 microvolts) and K-complexes (high voltage spikes, seen intermittently).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. REM Sleep: Rapid eye movement (REM) sleep is associated with vivid dreaming, and the EEG shows beta waves, and the return of alpha waves, hence called paradoxical sleep (as the person is sleeping but EEG is the same as that of an awake person). There are no sleep spindles present in REM sleep.

 

Option B. Stage 1 NREM Sleep: This is a light stage of sleep that serves as a transition from wakefulness to sleep. The EEG shows loss of alpha waves, predominance of theta waves. Sleep spindles are not typically seen in this stage.

 

Option D. Stage 3 NREM Sleep: This stage of sleep, also known as slow-wave sleep, is characterized by high-amplitude, low-frequency (delta) waves. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 487.

choices.text: Body dysmorphic disorder

questions.text: A 16-year-old individual presents to the clinic with a history of persistent discomfort with their assigned gender and a strong desire to be of another gender. This individual has expressed these feelings since early childhood and has experienced significant distress due to these feelings. The individual does not have any history of psychosis or other psychiatric disorders. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this individual?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gender dysphoria. 

 

Option B:

 

Gender dysphoria is characterized by a marked incongruence between one's experienced gender and assigned gender, lasting at least six months and causing significant distress or impairment in social or occupational functioning. This is the most appropriate diagnosis for the individual described in the question, who presented with persistent discomfort with their assigned gender and desire to be another gender.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Transvestic disorder is characterized by a recurrent and intense sexual arousal from cross-dressing, which often leads to significant distress or impairment in social or occupational functioning. This diagnosis is not appropriate for the individual described in the question, as their distress is not related to cross-dressing or sexual arousal.

 

Option C. Schizophrenia is characterized by delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, and/or disorganized or catatonic behavior. There is no indication in the provided information that the individual has symptoms consistent with schizophrenia.

 

Option D. Body dysmorphic disorder is characterized by a preoccupation with one or more perceived defects or flaws in physical appearance, which are not observable or appear slight to others. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gender dysphoria (gender incongruence) is characterized by incongruence between the experienced gender (the gender with which an individual identifies) and the one they were born with (referred to as assigned gender).

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 547.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a complaint of low sexual desire. She reports that her symptoms have caused her significant distress and strain on her relationship with her partner. The patient is otherwise healthy and her medical history is unremarkable. The physician considers pharmacotherapy to manage her condition. Which of the following medications is FDA-approved specifically for the treatment of Female Sexual Interest/Arousal Disorder (FSIAD) in premenopausal women?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Flibanserin

 

Explanation: 

 

Flibanserin is an FDA-approved medication specifically indicated for the treatment of premenopausal women with hypoactive sexual desire disorder (HSDD), now encompassed under Female Sexual Interest/Arousal Disorder (FSIAD). Flibanserin works by modulating serotonin, dopamine, and norepinephrine levels in the brain, which are thought to play a role in sexual desire. It is prescribed to enhance sexual desire in women who have not yet reached menopause and who have low sexual desire regardless of the type of sexual activity, the situation, or the sexual partner.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A) Sildenafil and Option B) Tadalafil: Both of these medications are phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE5) inhibitors primarily used to treat erectile dysfunction in men. While there have been studies exploring their use in women for various conditions, they are not FDA-approved specifically for the treatment of FSIAD in women.

 

Option C) Bupropion: Bupropion is an antidepressant that can have positive effects on sexual desire as a side effect due to its mechanism of action, which includes dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake inhibition. However, it is not specifically FDA-approved for the treatment of FSIAD in women.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flibanserin is a medication that is FDA-approved specifically for the treatment of Female Sexual Interest/Arousal Disorder (FSIAD) in premenopausal women. FSIAD refers to a condition in which a woman experiences a persistent or recurrent decrease in sexual interest or arousal, which leads to significant distress or interpersonal difficulties.

 

Flibanserin is a novel medication that acts as a selective serotonin 1A receptor agonist and a serotonin 2A receptor antagonist.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 530.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man presents to the clinic with a chief complaint of difficulty maintaining erections for the past 6 months. He reports that his erections are sometimes adequate at the beginning of sexual activity, but he loses them before reaching climax. He is able to achieve nocturnal erections and has no difficulty with erections during masturbation. His medical history is significant for hypertension, which is well-controlled with hydrochlorothiazide. The patient denies any recent stressful events, and his relationship with his partner is stable. He denies any history of alcohol or drug use. What is the most likely cause of the patient's erectile dysfunction?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Performance anxiety

 

Option A:

 

This patient's history indicates that he is able to achieve and maintain erections during nocturnal events and masturbation, suggesting that his erectile dysfunction is not related to a physical or organic cause. Performance anxiety is the most likely cause of this patient's erectile dysfunction. Psychogenic erectile dysfunction is commonly caused by performance anxiety, which is a form of situational anxiety that can lead to difficulty maintaining erections during sexual activity. Given the patient's ability to achieve erections during nocturnal events and masturbation, this indicates that his erectile dysfunction is likely due to psychological factors.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Hypertension is a common cause of organic erectile dysfunction. However, this patient's hypertension is well-controlled, and his ability to achieve erections during nocturnal events and masturbation suggests that hypertension is not the cause of his erectile dysfunction.

 

Option C. Hydrochlorothiazide use can be associated with erectile dysfunction as a side effect. However, this patient's ability to achieve erections during nocturnal events and masturbation again indicates that the cause is likely psychogenic rather than medication-related.

 

Option D. Vascular insufficiency is another potential cause of organic erectile dysfunction. However, this patient's ability to achieve erections during nocturnal events and masturbation suggests that vascular insufficiency is not the primary cause of his erectile dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of morning or nocturnal erections in a patient with erectile dysfunction suggests a psychogenic cause of the dysfunction.

 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 520-521.

choices.text: A 25-year-old man who experiences ejaculation within 30 seconds of penetration on 80% of occasions over the past 6 months
A 35-year-old man who experiences ejaculation within 1 minute of penetration on 25% of occasions over the past 2 months
A 45-year-old man who experiences ejaculation within 1.5 minutes of penetration on 90% of occasions over the past 3 months
A 55-year-old man who experiences ejaculation within 45 seconds of penetration on 50% of occasions over the past 1 month

questions.text: Which of the following patients will be diagnosed with premature ejaculation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A 25-year-old man who experiences ejaculation within 30 seconds of penetration on 80% of occasions over the past 6 months

 

Option A: 

 

Premature ejaculation (PE) is a common male sexual dysfunction characterized by ejaculation occurring too soon during sexual activity, leading to distress, frustration, or avoidance of sexual intimacy. The Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition (DSM-5) defines PE as a persistent or recurrent pattern of ejaculation occurring during partnered sexual activity within approximately one minute following vaginal penetration and before the individual wishes it, for at least 6 months.

 

In this question, option A is the most fitting case for the diagnosis of premature ejaculation. The patient experiences ejaculation within 30 seconds of penetration (which is less than 1 minute), and this has been occurring on 80% of occasions over the past 6 months.     

 

Other Options:
