Option B. Does not meet the diagnostic criteria because the patient experiences ejaculation within 1 minute on only 25% of occasions, which is not considered a recurrent pattern.

 

Option C. Does not meet the diagnostic criteria because the patient experiences ejaculation within 1.5 minutes, which is beyond the 1-minute threshold specified in the DSM-5.

 

Option D. Does not meet the diagnostic criteria because the duration of the problem is only 1 month, which is considerably less than the 6-month duration specified in the DSM-5.

 

Educational objective: 

 

Premature ejaculation is defined as ejaculation occurring within 1 minute of penetration for at least 6 months. It is usually psychogenic. 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 523

choices.text: Testosterone replacement therapy

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to your clinic complaining of premature ejaculation. He reports that this issue has been affecting his relationship with his partner and is seeking treatment. Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Paroxetine

 

Option A:

 

Premature ejaculation (PE) is a common male sexual dysfunction characterized by ejaculation that occurs sooner than desired, either before or shortly after penetration, causing distress to one or both partners. According to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, 5th Edition (DSM-5), PE is diagnosed if ejaculation happens within 1 minute of penetration for a duration of more than 6 months, and if it causes significant distress to the individual. The treatment of PE focuses on behavioral and pharmacological interventions. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), such as paroxetine, have been found to be effective in treating PE due to their ability to delay ejaculation. Paroxetine is considered the most effective SSRI for this purpose, and it is typically used off-label as the first-line treatment for PE. The exact mechanism is not well understood but is thought to involve the inhibition of serotonin reuptake in the central nervous system, which increases synaptic serotonin levels and delays ejaculation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Sildenafil: Sildenafil is a phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5) inhibitor primarily used to treat erectile dysfunction (ED). While it may have some limited benefit in patients with both ED and PE, it is not the first-line treatment for PE alone.

 

Option C. Testosterone replacement therapy: Testosterone therapy is indicated for men with hypogonadism or low testosterone levels, which can lead to various sexual dysfunctions. However, it is not the first-line treatment for PE in men with normal testosterone levels.

 

Option D. Tadalafil: Tadalafil is another PDE-5 inhibitor used to treat ED. Like sildenafil, it may have some limited benefit in patients with both ED and PE, but it is not the first-line treatment for PE alone.

 

Educational objective:

 

Treatment of premature ejaculation include:

 

  • SSRIs
  • Squeeze technique (coronal ridge of glans)
  • Stop-start technique (semans technique)
  • Sex therapy

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 530.

choices.text: Sensate focus exercises

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents to your clinic with concerns about premature ejaculation. He has been experiencing this issue for the past 8 months and it is affecting his relationship with his partner. The patient is interested in exploring non-pharmacological treatment options. Which of the following behavioral techniques is considered an effective first-line intervention for premature ejaculation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Squeeze technique

 

Option A:

 

Behavioral interventions can be effective in managing premature ejaculation (PE) and are often used as first-line treatments, either alone or in combination with pharmacological interventions. The main goal of these techniques is to help individuals gain better control over the timing of their ejaculation. Squeeze technique, developed by Masters and Johnson, is a commonly used behavioral intervention for PE. It involves the man or his partner applying firm pressure to the frenulum of the penis just before ejaculation, effectively interrupting the ejaculatory reflex and delaying ejaculation. With practice, men can learn to recognize their pre-ejaculatory sensations and apply the technique as needed.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Kegel exercises: Kegel exercises, or pelvic floor muscle exercises, can help strengthen the muscles that control ejaculation. While they may be beneficial in some cases of PE, particularly when the pelvic floor muscles are weak, they are not typically considered the first-line behavioral intervention for PE.

 

Option C. Relaxation training: Relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, and mindfulness, can help reduce anxiety and stress, which may contribute to PE. However, while relaxation training can be a helpful adjunct to other treatments, it is not considered a first-line behavioral intervention specifically for PE.

 

Option D. Sensate focus exercises: Sensate focus exercises involve couples engaging in a series of touching and caressing activities to help reduce performance anxiety and promote relaxation. Although these exercises can be helpful for various sexual dysfunctions, they are not a first-line behavioral intervention specifically for PE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The squeeze technique is a specific non-pharmacological method used to manage premature ejaculation. It involves squeezing the penis (coronal ridge of glans) before ejaculation to help delay it. Another technique used for premature ejaculation is stop-start technique (aka Seman’s technique). This technique involves sexual stimulation until the man recognizes that he is about to ejaculate. The stimulation is then removed for about 30 seconds and then resumed.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 532.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and is referred to a child psychiatrist for management. He has significant difficulties with social interaction and communication, as well as repetitive behaviors and restricted interests. He also demonstrates irritability, aggression, and self-injurious behavior. Which of the following medications is most likely to be effective in managing the irritability and aggression associated with his ASD?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Risperidone

 

Option C:

 

Risperidone is an atypical antipsychotic that has been approved by the FDA for the treatment of irritability associated with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) in children and adolescents. It can help manage symptoms such as aggression, self-injurious behavior, and severe tantrums. Risperidone works by affecting the levels of neurotransmitters in the brain, which can help to stabilize mood and reduce behavioral issues in children with ASD.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fluoxetine: Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) primarily used for the treatment of depression and anxiety disorders. While SSRIs can sometimes be used in ASD to manage associated anxiety or depression, they are not typically the first choice for irritability and aggression in ASD.

 

Option B. Methylphenidate: Methylphenidate is a stimulant medication commonly used to treat Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD). While it can help with focus and attention in children with ADHD, it is not primarily used for irritability and aggression in ASD.

 

Option D. Atomoxetine: Atomoxetine is a non-stimulant medication used to treat ADHD. Like methylphenidate, it is not the first choice for managing irritability and aggression in children with ASD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Risperidone is an atypical antipsychotic that has been specifically approved for the treatment of irritability associated with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) in children and adolescents, including symptoms such as aggression, self-injurious behavior, and temper tantrums.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 128.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to her physician with complaints of feeling sad, lack of interest and having difficulty falling asleep for the past two months. She also mentions that she feels tired most of the time and it's affecting her work performance. She has no history of hallucinations or delusions. Her physician suspects a common psychiatric disorder. Based on the patient's symptoms, which of the following best describes the category of the suspected disorder?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neurosis

 

Option B:

 

The patient's presentation of persistent sadness, lack of interest (anhedonia), insomnia, and fatigue is suggestive of a mood disorder, most likely major depressive disorder. These symptoms fall under the category of what was historically referred to as "neuroses," which encompasses conditions such as anxiety disorders, depressive disorders, and other related conditions that do not involve a break with reality (as seen in psychotic disorders). It's important to note that the term "neurosis" is largely outdated in contemporary psychiatric classification and is no longer used in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5). Instead, these conditions are classified under specific diagnostic categories such as depressive disorders, anxiety disorders, etc.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Psychosis or Psychotic disorders are characterized by a lack of awareness of the illness (absent insight) and impaired reality testing (i.e. loss of touch with reality). Delusions and hallucinations are examples of psychotic symptoms. Schizophrenia and bipolar disorder are common types of psychotic disorders. There is no history suggestive of psychotic disorders in the given case.

 

Option C. Personality disorders involve enduring patterns of inner experience and behavior that deviate markedly from the expectations of the individual's culture. The patient's symptoms seem more episodic and related to mood, which doesn't fit the typical presentation of a personality disorder.

 

Option D. Substance-induced disorder involves psychiatric symptoms that are directly attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication, or toxin exposure). There's no information provided to suggest that the patient's symptoms are related to substance use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Psychiatric disorders can be broadly categorized into psychoses and neuroses.

 

 

It is important to note that the classification between psychotic and neurotic disorders is now considered as arbitrary as some patients with psychotic disorders may have insight into their illness, while some patients with neurotic disorders may lack insight.

 

Ref: Shorter Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page 27.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male presents with complaints of excessive daytime sleepiness for the past two years. He denies any episodes of sudden muscle weakness, hallucinations, or sleep paralysis. A polysomnography followed by a multiple sleep latency test shows a short sleep latency of 6 minutes and three sleep-onset REM periods.  Which type of narcolepsy does this patient most likely have?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type 2 Narcolepsy.

 

Option B:

 

Type 2 Narcolepsy, also known as Narcolepsy without cataplexy, features excessive daytime sleepiness but without cataplexy. Patients with type 2 narcolepsy typically have less severe symptoms and may have a normal hypocretin (orexin) level. The presence of two or more sleep-onset REM periods during the MSLT supports the diagnosis of narcolepsy, and the absence of cataplexy in this patient suggests that it is type 2 narcolepsy. Since the patient does not report any episodes of cataplexy and the MSLT shows multiple sleep-onset REM periods, type 2 narcolepsy is the most likely diagnosis. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.

 

Type 1 Narcolepsy is associated with cataplexy (sudden and transient episodes of muscle weakness), and it typically shows a low hypocretin level in the cerebrospinal fluid.

 

Option C.

 

Narcolepsy with cataplexy is essentially another term for Type 1 Narcolepsy, which our patient does not have since he denies any episodes of sudden muscle weakness.

 

Option D.

 

Idiopathic hypersomnia is another central hypersomnia disorder, but it is characterized by long unrefreshing naps and a lack of sleep-onset REM periods.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th edition, Page 171-172.

questions.text: A 25-year-old presents to Psychiatry OPD with complaints of hearing his own thoughts in the ear. Which of the following best fits the above description?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thought echo

 

Option B:

 

The patient's complaint of hearing his own thoughts audibly, as if they are echoing in his ears, aligns with the definition of a thought echo.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Thought insertion: The patient feels that some external agency is inserting foreign thoughts into his mind. The scenario doesn't describe this phenomenon.

 

Option C: Pseudohallucination: Pseudohallucinations fulfils all the criteria of hallucinations with the exception that they are experienced in the ‘inner and subjective space’.

 

Option D: Delusion: Delusions are false beliefs that are unshakeable and cannot be explained on the basis of a person's social and cultural background. The patient isn't expressing a false belief but rather an abnormal perceptual experience related to his thoughts.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Thought echo is a specific type of auditory hallucination where an individual hears a voice, which says aloud whatever the patient would think. It is also known as audible thoughts. It is included in Schneiderian First Rank Symptoms of Schizophrenia while Pseudohallucinations are experienced in "inner and subjective space" rather than appearing to come from the external world.

 

Ref: Fish’s Clinical Psychopathology, 5th edition, Page No 30.

choices.text: Sensorimotor, Preoperational, Concrete operational, Formal operational

questions.text: A 35-year-old man begins attending therapy sessions to address long-standing feelings of anxiety and low self-esteem. During the sessions, the therapist utilizes the topographical theory of mind to help the patient better understand the underlying cause of his emotions and behaviors. According to this theory, which of the following represents the correct organization of the human psyche?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conscious, Preconscious, Unconscious

 

Option B:

 

The topographical theory of mind, proposed by Sigmund Freud, divides the human psyche into three main parts: the conscious, preconscious, and unconscious. Option B correctly represents this organization.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Id, Ego, Superego represent Freud's structural theory of mind, which is a different conceptualization focusing on the interplay between the instinctual drives (Id), the moral conscience (Superego), and the realistic mediator (Ego).

 

Option C. The term "subconscious" is not typically used in Freud's psychoanalytic theory. Freud's topographical model specifically refers to the conscious, preconscious, and unconscious.

 

Option D. Sensorimotor, Preoperational, Concrete operational, and Formal operational stages are associated with Jean Piaget's theory of cognitive development, not Freud's topographical theory of mind.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The topographical theory of mind, proposed by Sigmund Freud, divides the human psyche into three distinct levels: the conscious, preconscious, and unconscious. According to this theory:

 

  • The conscious consists of thoughts and perceptions that are currently in an individual's awareness.
  • The preconscious contains thoughts, memories, and knowledge that are not currently in conscious awareness but can be easily brought to consciousness.
  • The unconscious consists of processes and content that are not directly accessible to consciousness, including repressed feelings, thoughts, and desires.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 1060.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic with symptoms of depression and anxiety. During her therapy sessions, the therapist applies the structural theory of mind to help her gain insight into her unconscious conflicts and their influence on her current mental state. According to this theory, which of the following components of the mind is responsible for mediating between the other two components, striving to maintain balance and harmony?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ego

 

Option B:

 

Ego is the correct answer. The ego is responsible for mediating between the other two components of the mind, the id and the superego. It operates on the reality principle and seeks to balance the desires of the id with the moral and ethical demands of the superego while taking into account the constraints of reality.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Id is the part of the mind that is driven by the pleasure principle and houses unconscious desires, wishes, and instincts. It is the most primitive part of the mind and seeks immediate gratification without considering the consequences. The id does not mediate between other components of the mind.

 

Option C. Superego represents the internalized values, morals, and societal expectations. It is responsible for evaluating right and wrong and for guiding behavior according to these moral principles. The superego does not mediate between other components of the mind.

 

Option D. Preconscious is not a component of the structural theory of mind, which consists of id, ego, and superego. The preconscious refers to a level of consciousness where information is not currently in awareness but can be easily accessed if needed.

 

Educational objective:

 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 1064.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is attending a therapy session with his wife. He has been having an extramarital affair for the past six months, but he frequently accuses his wife of being unfaithful, despite her repeated assurances that she is loyal. The therapist suspects that the man is employing a defense mechanism to cope with his guilt. Which of the following defense mechanisms is the man most likely using?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Projection

 

Option A:

 

Projection is a defense mechanism where an individual attributes their own unacceptable thoughts or feelings onto someone else. In this scenario, the husband is projecting his guilt and infidelity onto his wife, accusing her of being unfaithful even though he is the one engaging in the extramarital affair.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Displacement is a defense mechanism where an individual redirects their emotions or impulses from the original target, which is a source of stress or conflict, to a less threatening or unrelated target. An example of displacement would be if the husband, feeling angry with his girlfriend, started shouting at his wife instead of confronting the girlfriend directly. In this scenario, the husband would be displacing his anger onto his wife, who is unrelated to the situation with the girlfriend, rather than dealing with the source of his anger directly.

 

Option C. Rationalization is a defense mechanism where an individual attempts to justify their behavior or feelings by providing logical explanations, even if these explanations are not entirely accurate or valid. If the husband were using rationalization, he might try to justify his affair by claiming that his wife was not meeting his emotional or physical needs.

 

Option D. Denial is a defense mechanism where an individual refuses to accept the reality of a situation or their feelings. If the husband were in denial, he might refuse to acknowledge that he was having an affair. 

 

Educational objective:

 

Projection is a narcissistic defence mechanism in which transfer of feelings about a person, onto, that person occurs. This is involved in the development of hallucinations and delusions. E.g. A husband, harbouring a desire for infidelity, starts accusing his wife of being unfaithful.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 1066.

choices.text: Behavioral therapy with an enuresis alarm

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic by his mother due to concerns about bedwetting. She reports that he has never achieved consistent nighttime dryness. He has no daytime urinary symptoms and is otherwise healthy. His physical examination, including a neurological assessment, is normal. Urinalysis is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most effective initial management for this child's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Behavioral therapy with an enuresis alarm

 

Option C:

 

The scenario describes a case of primary nocturnal enuresis (bedwetting) in a 7-year-old boy, which is defined as nighttime wetting in a child who has never achieved consistent dryness at night. The first line of management for primary nocturnal enuresis is typically non-pharmacological, and the most effective initial treatment is the use of a behavioral intervention such as an enuresis alarm. The alarm system detects moisture and wakes the child so they can use the bathroom. Over time, the child learns to associate the sensation of a full bladder with the need to awaken and go to the toilet, or they increasingly hold urine throughout the night.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Anticholinergic medications: These are usually reserved for children with daytime symptoms suggestive of an overactive bladder, such as urgency and frequency, which is not the case here.

 

Option B. Intranasal desmopressin: Desmopressin is a synthetic analog of vasopressin that can be used for the treatment of nocturnal enuresis, primarily when bedwetting is causing significant distress and other interventions have failed. It's not usually the first line of management.

 

Option D. Tricyclic antidepressants: Tricyclic antidepressants, like imipramine, have been used historically for enuresis but are not typically recommended as first-line therapy due to their side effect profile and the risk of toxicity in overdose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sleep-related enuresis is usually psychogenic (e.g. due to ‘sibling rivalry’). Rule out organic causes before making a diagnosis of psychogenic nocturnal enuresis (e.g. DM, DI, UTIs, obstructions). The treatment of choice is Bed alarms (behavioural therapy). The drug of choice is desmopressin. TCAs (like imipramine) can be used too.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 515.

choices.text: Periodic limb movement disorder

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his wife, who reports that her husband has been moving his legs constantly during sleep, leading to her being kicked multiple times each night. The husband states that he has no recollection of these movements. He mentions feeling fatigued upon waking up in the morning, despite sleeping for 7 to 8 hours each night. His medical history is unremarkable, and he takes no medications. Physical and neurological examinations are normal. Which of the following represents the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Periodic limb movement disorder

 

Option C:

 

The patient's symptoms are suggestive of Periodic Limb Movement Disorder (PLMD). PLMD is characterized by involuntary limb movements during sleep, which the patient is typically unaware of but can significantly disrupt sleep quality, leading to daytime fatigue. Key features supporting this diagnosis in this patient include:

 

  • Involuntary movements of the legs during sleep: The wife's report of her husband moving his legs constantly and kicking during sleep is a hallmark of PLMD.
  • No recollection of these movements: Patients with PLMD are usually unaware of their limb movements during sleep.
  • Daytime fatigue: Despite sleeping for an adequate duration, the patient feels fatigued upon waking up, indicating disrupted sleep quality.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Restless legs syndrome (RLS): While RLS involves uncomfortable sensations in the legs and an urge to move them, typically occurring in the evening or at rest, it does not usually involve involuntary leg movements during sleep that are reported by a bed partner.

 

Option B. Sleep terror disorder: This involves episodes of screaming, intense fear, and flailing while still asleep, often accompanied by sleepwalking. It is more common in children and doesn't align with the symptom of involuntary leg movements.

 

Option D. Narcolepsy: Narcolepsy presents with excessive daytime sleepiness, cataplexy (brief episodes of muscle weakness), sleep paralysis, and hypnagogic hallucinations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Periodic limb movement disorder (previously called nocturnal myoclonus) is characterized by repetitive, involuntary limb movements during sleep, often leading to sleep disturbance and daytime fatigue. It occurs primarily in NREM sleep. It is seen folate deficiency, renal disease, anemia and with the antidepressant use. It is distinct from restless legs syndrome, which involves an uncomfortable urge to move the legs while awake and at rest.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 501.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman who recently lost her husband to cancer decides to volunteer at a local hospice to support terminally ill patients and their families. Her friends notice that she seems to have found a sense of purpose and emotional relief through this work. Which of the following defense mechanisms is the woman most likely utilizing to cope with her grief?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Altruism

 

Option D:

 

Altruism is a defense mechanism where an individual copes with their own difficulties or emotional conflicts by dedicating themselves to the well-being of others. In this case, the woman has found a sense of purpose and emotional relief by volunteering at the hospice and supporting patients and their families.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Humor: Defense mechanism where an individual uses comedy or jokes to deal with a difficult situation or emotions. The woman's actions in the scenario do not involve humor.

 

Option B. Rationalization: Defense mechanism where an individual explains or justifies their behavior or emotions using logical reasoning. The woman's actions in the scenario do not involve rationalization.

 

Option C. Sublimation: Defense mechanism where an individual redirects socially unacceptable desires or impulses into more socially acceptable activities or channels. While volunteering at a hospice is a socially acceptable activity, the woman is not channeling unacceptable impulses or thoughts; she's coping with her grief by helping others in a similar situation.

 

Educational objective:

 

Altruism is the use of a social cause to deal with own emotions. E.g. After losing his son in an accident while driving drunk, a man launched an anti-drunk driving campaign, educating others about the dangers of driving under the influence.


Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 1067.
